Topic.Title: How will Congress Vote on Syria ?

Message.Msg: That's been the Repugnantcon strategy ever since Obama was elected. They might as well stay home and raise money if they're going to do that. So you want them to score political points rather than do what's right for the nation and debate the issue? There are no cats left in your bag, Don -- you've let them all out.

Message.Msg: We agree on one more thing, Spart. But Don's vote for government posturing and grandstanding is already counted. I'm just glad my e-mail "lobbying" had some effect.
Yes Don. It's 45 years later. Same-same for the folks who are always quoting Dolly Madison. All of us hope to improve -- to be wiser, or at least more thoughtful, at 60 than we were at 20.

Message.Title: Evcerot part 3 last
Message.Msg: So both sides of any conflict, not to mention civilians everywhere, are better off if neither of them uses chemical weapons. But that requires believing that your opponent will never use them, no matter what. And the only way to do that, short of removing them from the planet entirely, is for everyone to just agree in advance to never use them and to really mean it. That becomes much harder if the norm is weakened because someone like Assad got away with it. It becomes a bit easier if everyone believes using chemical weapons will cost you a few inbound U.S. cruise missiles. That’s why the Obama administration apparently wants to fire cruise missiles at Syria, even though it won’t end the suffering, end the war or even really hurt Assad that much.
I must have become tired of typing "Excerpt"
Why did I know you would try to rationalize Kerry,s hypocrisy?....let me know when Kerry comes up with the proof Assad gassed his own people
